Mary Travers, of Peter, Paul and Mary, peace ambassador and teacher, and one of America's great folk artists, has passed away. 
 
 
 Here is a youtube from their 1966 Tonight In Person appearance. 
 
 YouTube - Peter Paul & Mary - Blowin in the wind
 
 
 "There's an old folk song that has a line in it that says, 'We shall study war no more'. And it is what all of us wish for the world. A time when we study war no more. The way to achieve that is to ask questions. This next song is just a beginning, and we ask you to ask the questions with us. Sing it with us. Because you were, and you are, and you will always be, blowing in the wind."
 
 - Mary Travers, Live in Japan, 1990

 Here is a youtube from their 1966 Tonight In Person appearance. 
 
 YouTube - Peter Paul & Mary - Blowin in the wind

 The answer has gone with the wind, unfortunately
snakespit
A great loss to the folk community. She was certainly an amazing singer/songwriter, and her influence has certainly shaped music as we know it today, and as we will know it for years to come.
antonia

She had such beautiful expression and wisdom in her voice that only seemed to deepen with time. They brought folk music to so many audiences, and the body of work they produced is enormous. I think they are also to be greatly credited for bringing so much folk music to children. They were (are, as well, since Peter and Paul are still alive) very generous as musicians.
 
 I remember being in a park once as a child and Paul was there with his guitar. He just started playing and singing for all the kids there. All the kids wound up there, dropping all else they were doing, sitting on the grass, listening to him perform. Talking about the music and songs too. He was also quite a teacher.
 
 The photo from the first link is all 3 of them at the 1963 March on Washington when Dr. King gave his I Have A Dream speech. I think Mary was also involved in the voter registration drive down south. I think of her, too, as a feminist. She was a strong and opinionated and inspiring woman who spoke her mind out on issues when others were reluctant to. Some looked at her and saw this gorgeous willowy blonde and thought there was nothing else going on. But anyone really listening to her sing, this strength and spirit and spunk belted out, could see that she was quite a principled and brave person, a lot of character, a thinking individual. Very encouraging and supportive of others, a quality I think increasingly out in her music, over the years.
 
 Here, you can see it, too in her rendition of the Hammer Song (I think it's the Newport Folk Festival). 
 
 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lUKB3PxG-0E&feature=related
 
 The New York Times ran an obituary, but I thought they really did a poor job summarizing her contributions, didn't really appreciate the history or person or music there, and were even a little nasty (e.g. they qualified the music as "commercial", etc).
 
 Some people wanted Mary to go into a closet when she got older and ill and when she was no longer their sex symbol. But Mary obviously knew she was a person, not a thing. She never stopped fighting and she never accepted the shallow definitions that others were imposing upon her, and then, as a middle-aged or older woman, and having gained weight. She was a self-disciplined and trained artist and kept reflecting that self-perception in her music, to anyone who knew how to listen to what was there on a deeper level. She kept speaking her mind and developing and deepening the artistry in her expression. She always carried herself with dignity, even more so in later years.
 
 They're so tight and connected in their performance together, as a group, at Newport. I reminded of how some jazz musicians do it up. It's just beautiful.
 
 Anyway, I see Mary Travers as an inspiring figure in music also. (And the New York Times can go jump in a lake.)

Easyrider

Back in 1963 or early 1964 I was a teenager working at the Atlantic Richfield station at the corner of Desert Inn Rd. and Maryland Pkwy in Las Vegas. Around 6 PM or so (could have been Saturday) a long, black limo pulls up. The right rear window rolls down and I'm looking at Peter, Paul, and Mary. Mary was in the middle in a mini skirt and long legs, with her long blonde hair and she looked really good. It was either Peter or Paul who asked directions to UNLV. They must have had a concert there that night. "Down Maryland Pkwy about 1 mile on the right," I said. I wanted to hop in there with them. And there they went, down the highways of their lives. It was a moment in time. One moment she looked young, and great, and had wonderful times ahead of her. Now she's gone. Time goes by so quickly.
 
 Edit: Here's a link with a picture: http://celebrating50.unlv.edu/timeline.html
 
 It was 1963
 
 I wonder what Mary's religious beliefs were? I can't find anything on the internet. Does anyone know?  I know either Peter or Paul is a Christian but I'd like to know what Mary thought.
 
 My favorite song of theirs is "Early Morning Rain."

 That's a great story from Nevada about the limo!

That's why I liked what Laura Bush said in that interview, that she was a feminist. It was a very Nixonesque moment in the Nimoy sense (only he could go to China).  I remember the 60's, I was in Chile, attending High School and later Uni, during those incredible years. We just couldn't understand what was going with the 'gringos'. Have they gone 'locos' ? To us they were just a bunch of rich spoiled kids, with nothing better to do and talking about things they knew nothing about. I am still of the same opinion about the hippies and the anti-war movement, bras burning women etc. The only sane voice was Martin Luther King jr. He was on a real mission.

Btw, Winston, in point of contrast to your comments about the sixties in the U.S., this song Peter, Paul and Mary did is just as good now as it was then:
 
 YouTube - Peter Paul & Mary - These times they are a-changing
 
 Youtube had another recording of the group doing it more recently in a church, but unfortunately, I see it is removed for copyright reasons. It was a great recording. (John Sebastian joins them on the harmonica.) You could really appreciate the way Mary Travers had deepened as a singer and performer. She does that same solo with the verse compassionately appealing to parents, but it has this even wiser aspect in her expression (now that she's lived more herself). Plus, there is this joyful and triumphant quality in her older artistry, that isn't yet evident in Mary as a younger performer.
 
 But anyway, you can see how relevant these issues today, as then. Through a comparison of the two pieces.

La Estrella Azul
 (Peteco Carabajal)
 
 Donde estará la estrella azul?,
 esa estrellita del alma;
 sus ojos suelen brillar
 perdidos en la inmensidad.
 
 A veces sueño que esta aquí
 y se ilumina el camino,
 cuando aparece el fulgor
 cerquita de mi corazón.
 
 Donde estará la estrella azul?,
 ya no podré con mi dolor;
 en otros cielos brillara
 esa estrellita del amor.
 
 En una lagrima quedo
 hasta perderse en el cielo;
 mi corazón se partió
 atravesado de penas.
 
 A nadie puedo preguntar
 con las palabras del alma;
 es mi tristeza un papel
 que el viento no deja caer.
 
 Donde estará la estrella azul?,

 esa estrellita del amor.

 que el viento no deja caer.
 
 Donde estará la estrella azul?,
 ya no podré con mi dolor;
 en otros cielos brillara
 esa estrellita del amor.
 
 Donde estará la estrella azul?,
 ya no podré con mi dolor;
 en otros cielos brillara
 esa estrellita del amor.
 
 En una lagrima quedo
 hasta perderse en el cielo;
 mi corazón se partió
 atravesado de penas.
 
 A nadie puedo preguntar
 con las palabras del alma;
 es mi tristeza un papel
 que el viento no deja caer.
 
 Donde estará la estrella azul?,
 ya no podré con mi dolor;
 en otros cielos brillara
 esa estrellita del amor.

 
 I know your intention is pure but, 
 
 Why do you quote something you don't understand a single word of ? 
 
 It is cr-ap, by the way. I don't like Peteco at all.
 
 Well, it is not all cr-ap, this verse is very good, sweet and sad:
 
 A nadie puedo preguntar
 con las palabras del alma;
 es mi tristeza un papel
 que el viento no deja caer.
 
 but the music is flat, horrible.
Winston Smith

She's magnificent and this is sad news, Winston, but ... compañera? Hard to believe that an Allende hater like yourself could feel that way about Mercedes Sosa.
 
 As well as, "Vaya con Dios?" From a perishable agnostic?
 
 What dramatis personae.

 
 The problem with ‘crusaders’ such as yourself is that you see everything in black and white, the ‘us’ and ‘them’ is how you divide the human race, and the ‘them’ is the enemy. You carry a big chip on your shoulder and pick up a fight with anyone who disagrees with you, insults always follow.
 People such as myself, see not only black and white but every shade of grey in between.
 You don’t know the meaning of the word ‘agnostic’. You don’t know the meaning of the word ‘skeptic’.
 You are not a bad person though, superficial yes, but bad, no. 
 Don’t worry about songs in Spanish, you not only need to learn the language but you have to live in Spain or South America for many years to understand the songs, to really understand the songs. You know nothing about Allende, you don’t know anything about Chile or Argentina, except what you read in tourist travel brochures.
 You know nothing about me. emoticon_xclown
 
 Now for something I really like and I hope you will like also :
 
 YouTube - THE MOTELS - TOTAL CONTROL LIVE VERSION
 
 Martha Davis was really something, what an underrated singer, but I don't care.
 
 Oh! one more thing you should have said 'dramatis persona' not 'personae', which is the plural form of persona. don't mangle latin, please stick to your lingo. emoticon_rolleyes
antonia

I know your intention is pure but, 
 
 Why do you quote something you don't understand a single word of ? 
 
 It is cr-ap, by the way. I don't like Peteco at all.
 
 Well, it is not all cr-ap, this verse is very good, sweet and sad:
 
 A nadie puedo preguntar
 con las palabras del alma;
 es mi tristeza un papel
 que el viento no deja caer.
 
 but the music is flat, horrible.

 
 So now we know that your alleged familarity with Mercedes Sosa is fraudulent. 
 
 Where would you be without youtube?
Winston Smith

I have casettes of Mercedes Sosa and one CD I bought years ago.
 I have LPs of Atahualpa Yupanqui and one of Angel Parra singing his compositions.
 
 It useless trying to talk to you. I give up.
 
 Adios y vaya con Dios
antonia

Adios y vaya con Dios

 
 Vaya con Vida.

Alright, back on topic, I've loved the music of Peter Paul & Mary for a long time. While I don't always agree with the extent of their politics, they were a great musical trio and I loved their passion and many of the things they stood for. There are some very nice vids of them online, particularly a color one of them performing 'Jane, Jane' in 1966 that really shows Mary Travers' enthusiasm, and a b&w one I particularly like of 'Early Mornin' Rain'.
jyoshu
